abstract.text: Add unique elements to your app’s document launch scene.

metadata.title: Customizing a document-based app’s launch experience

inlineContent.text: In iOS 18 and later, you can customize the document browsing experience for your app, such as setting the title and action buttons, configuring the background, and adding custom assets to the scene.
For information about adopting the document-based launch experience SwiftUI, read
To create a customized document launch experience, follow these steps:
Declare your supported document types in the Document Types section of your app target’s Info tab.
Set the Supports Document Browser key (
) in the Custom iOS Target Properties section of the Info tab.
Create a
subclass for each document type your app supports.
Create a
subclass for your app, and have the subclass adopt the
protocol.
Set your document view subclass as your app’s root view controller. Alternatively, you can embed your
subclass in a navigation controller, and set that as the root view controller.
Implement your delegate’s
method to configure your document view.
Configure the launch scene using the document view controller’s
property.
When setting the document type, provide a name and the Uniform Type Identifier for your documents. Add the
key with a value of
(read-only) or
(if your app both reads and writes the document type). Finally, add a
key, and set its value to the name of your
subclass for this document type.
When implementing your
method, verify that you have a valid document and a valid view before updating the view. For more information, see

code: // Make sure you have a valid document.
guard let document = document as? MyDocument else { return }
// Make sure you have a valid view.

inlineContent.text: The document viewer uses app intents to create new documents. It also uses the
structure to specify the different ways your app can create documents.
already provides a default intent and the corresponding
enumeration value.
To add your own intents, start by extending
and adding values for your intents.

to the default create document action.

protocol’s

inlineContent.text: On iPad, iPhone, and Vision Pro (for compatible iPad apps), the system displays a launch scene that contains a title and any document creation buttons. It also displays the document browser as a sheet over this view. Use your document view controller’s
property to customize this scene as follows:
Set the
property to change the name that appears in the title view. By default, the controller uses your app’s name.
Modify the
property to configure the scene’s background.
Use the
or
to place
objects in front of or behind the title view.
Set the
or
properties to add buttons to the title view. If you don’t modify the
property, the controller adds a Create Document button as the default primary action.
Use
to access and configure the document browser controller.
Typically, you configure the launch options in your view controller’s
method.

code: // Assign the view controller as the browser delegate.
// Provide an action for the secondary action.

abstract.text: The app’s role with respect to the document type.
Create, save, and open documents in a multiplatform app.

doc://com.apple.documentation/documentat.title: Building a document-based app with SwiftUI

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your iOS, iPadOS, or tvOS app.
An abstract base class for managing discrete portions of your app’s data.
An app intent that creates new documents for your app.
A view controller for browsing and performing actions on documents that you store locally and in the cloud.
The document browser’s import modes.
The current intent that defines how your app creates a document.
The protocol you implement to respond as the user interacts with the document browser.
Asks the delegate to create a new document.
A view controller that previews, opens, or prints files with a file format that your app can’t handle directly.
A view controller that provides access to documents or destinations outside your app’s sandbox.
A view controller that manages and presents a document stored locally or in the cloud.
Options for customizing the document launch view.
A view that appears behind the title view in the launch scene.
The document browser view controller.
Creates an action that uses the specified intent.
A view that appears in front of the title view in the launch scene.
The launch scene’s primary action.
The launch scene’s secondary action.
The title that appears in the title view.
Provides an opportunity to configure the view after the system loads the controller’s document into memory.
Options that customize a document-based app’s launch view.
A configuration that describes the launch scene’s background.
An object that manages the content for a rectangular area on the screen.
Called after the controller’s view is loaded into memory.
Give users access to their local or remote documents from within your app.

doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKi.title: Adding a document browser to your app

abstract.text: Implement a custom document file format to manage user interactions with files on different cloud storage providers.

doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKi.title: Building a document browser app for custom file formats

abstract.text: Use a document browser to provide access to the user’s text files.
Use a document picker to access the content of a directory outside your app’s container.
Manage your interface using view controllers and facilitate navigation around your app’s content.
